Solution:

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis include alcohol (which this patient does not use) and gallstones (which were not seen on the ultrasound). Other possible causes include hypertriglyceridemia (third most common), medications (eg, azathioprine, valproic acid, thiazide diuretics), infections (eg, cytomegalovirus [CMV]), recent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), and trauma. The serum triglyceride level generally must be >1,000 mg/dl to be considered a potential cause of pancreatitis. The yellow-red papules on this patient's arms and shoulders suggest eruptive xanthomas, which are due to subcutaneous fat deposition. Eruptive xanthomas are usually associated with marked hypertriglyceridemia (>1,000 mg/dl), typically due to familial hypertriglyceridemia (which may a so explain the patient's father's myocardial infarction at age 42). A fasting serum lipid profile can determine if hypertriglyceridemia is the underlying cause of this patient's xanthomas and pancreatitis.

His previous hospitalizations for vomiting and epigastric pain that radiates to the back raise suspicion for recurrent episodes of acute alcoholic pancreatitis. Patients with chronic pancreatitis may initially be asymptomatic, but disease progression ultimately leads to malabsorption, steatorrhea, and postprandial epigastric pain that can become continuous. Crystalloid fluid infusion The patient's findings are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Aggressive hydration with crystalloids (e.g., lactated Ringer's solution) is the most important measure in managing patients with acute pancreatitis and signs of hypovolemia (tachycardia, elevated hematocrit, and BUN/creatinine ratio > 20:1), such as this man. Hypovolemia in patients with pancreatitis is often multifactorial (e.g., vomiting, reduced oral intake, and third spacing of fluid), which may increase the risk of a complicated course (e.g., necrotizing pancreatitis or organ failure). While normal saline may also be used as replacement fluid, lactated Ringer's solution is usually preferred because large quantities of normal saline can cause non-anion gap hyperchloremic acidosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old alcoholic presents to the Emergency Department with central abdominal pain and vomiting. She prefers to sit up as the pain aggravates on lying supine and on eating. On examination, her pulse rate is 140/min, her temperature is 38.2°C, and there is periumbilical discoloration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute pancreatitis Recognized causes of acute pancreatitis include gallstones, alcohol, trauma, certain drugs (e.g. steroids, azathioprine, and thiazide diuretics), mumps, autoimmune pancreatitis, scorpion venom (rare), hyperlipidaemia, hypercalcaemia, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis results from the early activation of pancreatic enzymes, producing autodigestion of the pancreas and surrounding tissues. Exposure of trypsinogen to lysosomal enzymes such as cathepsin B has been elucidated as a mechanism for early trypsin activation. Digestive enzyme release is amplified as acinar cells lyse, leading to a vicious cycle of inflammation and necrosis. The common presentations include central abdominal pain that starts at a low intensity and gradually increases in severity. The pain may radiate to the back, may be associated with nausea and vomiting, and may be improved by sitting forward. On examination, the patient may be tachycardic with fever and jaundice; in acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis, there may be periumbilical discoloration (Cullen’s sign) or bruising of the flanks (Grey–Turner’s sign). Blood tests will usually show significantly raised serum amylase levels.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a recurrent rash. He has multiple skin lesions on his legs, buttocks, and around his mouth. The rash first appeared a year ago and tends to resolve spontaneously in one location before reappearing in another location a few days later. It begins with painless, reddish spots that gradually increase in size and then develop into painful and itchy blisters. One year ago, the patient was diagnosed with major depressive syndrome and was started on fluoxetine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple crusty patches with central areas of bronze-colored induration, as well as tender eruptive lesions with irregular borders on his legs, buttocks, and around his lips. The Nikolsky sign is negative. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 88 μm3, and serum glucose is 210 mg/dL. A skin biopsy of the lesion shows epidermal necrosis. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found in this patient?

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased fasting serum glucagon level Increased fasting glucagon levels indicate glucagonoma , a pancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasm. Excess glucagon increases gluconeogenesis and inhibits glycolysis, causing hyperglycemia and/or mild diabetes. Anemia may be a result of anemia or chronic illness or directly related to the inhibitory effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis. As seen here, patients with glucagonoma can also present with neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, dementia, and ataxia). Necrolytic migratory erythema is characterized by the occurrence of multiple, centrifugally spreading erythemas, located predominantly on the face, perineum, and lower extremities, which develop into painful and pruritic crusty patches with central areas of bronze-colored induration. These lesions tend to resolve and then reappear in a different location.

Diabetes and dermatitis together should raise suspicion of glucagonoma. Glucagonoma typically presents with mild diabetes and necrolytic migratory erythema. Patients with glucagonoma commonly experience an enlarged, sensitive tongue. Glucagon is a catabolic hormone and most patients with glucagonoma present with malnutrition. A diagnosis of glucagonoma can be confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels, which are typically higher than 500 pg/mL. The rash associated with glucagonoma is believed to be caused by low levels of amino acids.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Villous atrophy is typically found in celiac disease, a malabsorptive condition that can cause chronic diarrhea and anemia. Secondary skin lesions can develop due to zinc malabsorption. While the skin lesions (especially perioral blistering lesions) in this condition may be very similar to necrolytic migratory erythema, they do not migrate and they do not have a central area of induration. Patients with the celiac disease commonly experience abdominal cramps and depression. However, hyperglycemia is not a typical finding. Option: B. Severely decreased serum zinc levels are typically found in zinc uptake deficiency (e.g., in acrodermatitis enteropathica), which can also present with chronic diarrhea and anemia. However, neither the hereditary form (manifests at a young age with failure to thrive) nor the acquired form (secondary to celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease) is associated with hyperglycemia. Furthermore, this patient lacks other symptoms of zinc deficiency, such as impaired taste, hypogonadism, or night blindness. Option: C. Furthermore, patients with Pemphigus vulgaris do not have hyperglycemia, chronic diarrhea, or weight loss.

questions.text: A 10-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of difficulty feeding and frequent non-bilious vomiting. His stool is soft and yellow-colored. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios and results from chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XY, +21 karyotype. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distention and normal bowel sounds. An X-ray of the abdomen with oral contrast is shown. The most likely cause of his condition is due to a defect in which of the following embryologic processes?

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rotation of ventral pancreatic bud During the embryologic development of the pancreas, the endoderm forms two buds: a ventral and a dorsal one. In the process of foregut rotation, the ventral pancreatic bud normally fuses with the dorsal pancreatic bud. A defect in this process can lead to the fusion of abnormally rotated buds, resulting in a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounding the duodenum ( annular pancreas ) and duodenal stenosis. questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding pancreatic injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Pancreatic injury is common following blunt abdominal trauma

options.label: B
options.text: Pancreatic injury is often accompanied by damage to the liver, spleen, and duodenum

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Pancreatic injury is common following blunt abdominal trauma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pancreatic injury is common following blunt abdominal trauma. Pancreatic injury is rare in blunt upper abdominal trauma because of the retroperitoneal position of the organ. Therefore, for the pancreas to be injured, the force of trauma has to be severe. Thus if pancreatic injury occurs, almost certainly the liver, duodenum, and spleen are damaged. Penetrating injuries to the back or upper abdomen have a higher incidence of pancreatic damage. The overall damage can be from simple contusion or laceration to major parenchymal and duct destruction; in extreme cases, there may be massive destruction of the pancreatic head where inevitably concomitant duodenal injury will be present. The integrity or otherwise of the pancreatic duct will decide the management.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic injuries are rare occurrences . Penetrating injuries into the abdomen are the most common injuries seen in adults. Isolated pancreatic injuries are uncommon, with up to 90% of patients presenting with associated injuries to other organs. The most common associated injury is to a hollow viscus, followed by the liver and spleen. CT scan is the investigation of choice to evaluate patients with abdominal trauma. CT findings such as peripancreatic hematomas , free fluid in the lesser sac, or abnormal thickening of Gerota's fascia suggest pancreatic injury. ERCP is the most reliable test to demonstrate pancreatic duct integrity. Isolated pancreatic amylase level measurement is not recommended due to normal serum amylase levels being present in up to 40% of patients with pancreatic duct transection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: B, C, & D. All other statements are true.

Extraedge:

The definitive treatment for pancreatic injuries is based on surgical findings. Major pancreatic resections are recommended for stable patients with isolated pancreatic injuries. Damage control surger y is indicated for complex injuries or unstable patients. Most deaths occur within 48 to 72 hours after trauma, and up to 75% of these are related to hypovolemic shock. The most common complication after pancreatic trauma is a persistent drain output or pancreatic fistula.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

In all cases of acute pancreatitis, there is a marked rise in serum amylase. All cases of acute pancreatitis do not cause a rise in serum amylase. A normal amylase in acute pancreatitis might occur when the disease is so severe that the entire pancreas has been destroyed and there is not enough pancreatic tissue left to elaborate the enzyme. Thus, a normal amylase in the presence of acute pancreatitis indicates a poor prognosis. A normal amylase level might also be because the blood has been taken too late and the patient has recovered from the acute attack, which has been transient.

Highyeild:

Acute pancreatitis (AP) is mild and self-limited in most patients, but 10-20% of patients may experience a rapidly progressive inflammatory response associated with a prolonged hospital stay, significant morbidity, and mortality. Severe pancreatitis has a mortality rate of 10-30% and is often caused by multiorgan dysfunction syndrome and septic complications. AP results from abnormal pancreatic enzyme activation , leading to autodigestion of pancreatic tissue and triggering an inflammatory response. Gallstones and ethanol abuse are the most common risk factors for AP. Clinical features include: epigastric pain, nausea/vomiting, and dehydration; severe cases may exhibit abdominal distention and rebound tenderness. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzyme levels, with lipase being a more specific marker than amylase. Treatment involves aggressive fluid resuscitation, analgesics, and enteral nutrition.

The proximal part of the dorsal duct persists as an accessory pancreatic duct. Late in the development or in the postnatal period, the ducts fuse. Failure of fusion of the embryological dorsal and ventral parts of the pancreas results in the pancreas divisum. In such a situation, which occurs.

Highyeild:

Pancreatic divisum Pancreatic divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas, caused by the failure of dorsal and ventral ducts to fuse during fetal development. There are three types of pancreas divisum based on the degree of fusion between the ducts. All types of pancreas divisum have a dominant dorsal duct, and pancreatic secretions flow through the accessory papilla. MRCP is often used for diagnosis, but ERCP is the gold standard of investigation . Operative dorsal duct sphincterotomy , with or without sphincteroplasty, is the preferred surgical treatment. questions.text: Which of the following are not parameters to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis in either the Ranson or Glasgow score?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Besides the other tests mentioned in the list, serum albumin, arterial oxygen saturation, lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) and aspartate transaminase (AST) are the other important factors. The assessment of severity is very important, so much so this must be performed within 48 hours of making the diagnosis. This is because of the difference in outcome in patients with mild and severe disease and therefore the pattern of management.

It was developed by Dr. John Ranson in 1974 and has since been widely used as a predictor of mortality in patients with acute pancreatitis. The Ranson score is composed of 11 variables, which are divided into two groups: clinical and laboratory. The clinical variables are age, WBC count, blood glucose, serum LDH, and AST, while the laboratory variables are serum calcium, arterial oxygen pressure, base deficit, BUN, hematocrit, and fluid sequestration. Each variable is scored from 0 to 4 based on its severity, with higher scores indicating a more severe disease. The scores for each variable are then added together to calculate the total Ranson score, which ranges from 0 to 11. A Ranson score of 3 or higher is considered to indicate severe acute pancreatitis and is associated with a higher risk of mortality. Other factors, such as the patient's overall health status and the presence of complications, may also influence the prognosis

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with weight loss and a persistent rash on her lower abdomen and perineum. She is diagnosed with necrolytic migrating erythema and additional workup demonstrates a hemoglobin A1c of 7.5%, hematocrit of 26%, and a large mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glucagonoma causes a syndrome of a characteristic rash, diabetes mellitus (as demonstrated by the elevated hemoglobin A1c in the scenario), anemia (as demonstrated by the hematocrit of 26%), weight loss, and elevated levels of circulating glucagon. Glucagonomas are usually present in the body or tail of the pancreas and easily identifiable on CT scanning of the abdomen. Treatment is surgical excision with distal pancreatectomy.

Highyeild:

Diabetes and dermatitis together should raise suspicion of glucagonoma. Glucagonoma typically presents with mild diabetes and necrolytic migratory erythema. Patients with glucagonoma commonly experience an enlarged, sensitive tongue. Glucagon is a catabolic hormone and most patients with glucagonoma present with malnutrition. A diagnosis of glucagonoma can be confirmed by measuring serum glucagon levels, which are typically higher than 500 pg/mL. The rash associated with glucagonoma is believed to be caused by low levels of amino acids.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, C, and D. The other islet cell tumors do not cause a characteristic rash.

Preoperative treatment for glucagonoma usually involves controlling diabetes, parenteral nutrition, and octreotide. Glucagonomas are often located in the body and tail of the pancreas and tend to be large tumors with metastases. Debulking operations are recommended for good operative candidates to relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A 38-year-old previously healthy male is hospitalized for 2 weeks with epigastric pain radiating to his back, nausea, and vomiting. Initial laboratory values revealed an elevated amylase level consistent with acute pancreatitis. Five weeks following discharge, he complains of early satiety, epigastric pain, and fevers. On presentation, his temperature is 38.9°C (102°F) and his heart rate is 120 beats/minute; his white blood cell (WBC) count is 24,000/mm3 and his amylase level is normal. He undergoes a CT scan demonstrating a 6 cm by 6 cm rim-enhancing fluid collection in the body of the pancreas. Which of the following would be the most definitive management of the fluid collection?

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudocysts are non epithelialized fluid collections that can present at the earliest 4 to 6 weeks after an episode of acute pancreatitis. The treatment for infected pancreatic pseudocysts involves percutaneous catheter drainage with antibiotics.

Highyeild:

Pseudocysts are a chronic collection of pancreatic fluid surrounded by fibrosis and granulation tissue. They account for 75% of cystic lesions of the pancreas and are commonly located in the lesser sac or within the substance of the gland. Pseudocysts can occur after acute or chronic pancreatitis, with alcohol being the most common cause. Symptoms include abdominal pain, early satiety, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and fever. Diagnosis is made with a CT scan of the abdomen, and treatment depends on the size and age of the pseudocyst, with drainage indicated for those larger than 5 cm. Pseudocyst complications include infection (14% most common), duodenal obstruction, pain due to expansion, rupture, hemorrhage (up to 10%), and abscess.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Antibiotics alone are not enough to manage infected pancreatic pseudocyst. Option: B & C. Aspiration of the fluid can be diagnostic but is not a definitive treatment, even with the addition of antibiotics. The internal drainage of pancreatic pseudocysts is contraindicated in the presence of infection but is the treatment of choice for mature, symptomatic, noninfected pseudocysts. Malignancy should be excluded if there is no preceding history of pancreatitis. Pseudocysts that are asymptomatic and noninfected can be observed.

Pseudocysts communicate with the pancreatic ductal system in up to 80% of cases, so external drainage creates a pathway for pancreatic duct leakage to and through the catheter exit site. Internal drainage methods include percutaneous catheter-based methods, endoscopic methods, and surgical methods. Surgical options include cystogastrostomy, Roux-en-Y cystojejunostomy, and cystoduodenostomy. The preferred modality is internal drainage of the cyst by cystojejunostomy , which has a slightly lower recurrence rate but is associated with significantly more blood loss and operative time.

Distal pancreatectomy is a surgical procedure where a portion of the pancreas is removed. It is typically performed in patients with inflammatory changes localized to the body and tail or no significant ductal dilatation. The procedure is associated with a significant risk of symptomatic recurrence. Long-term outcomes reveal good pain relief in only 60% of patients, with completion pancreatectomy required for pain relief in 13% of patients.

Internal drainage is the treatment of choice for symptomatic noninfected pancreatic pseudocysts Option: D. external drainage which is the treatment of choice for infected pseudocysts but is contraindicated if malignancy is suspected.

Laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy is feasible for the removal of focal lesions of the distal pancreas, but it is more difficult in the setting of chronic pancreatitis. questions.text: A 51-year-old man with a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) has an elevated gastrin level and is suspected to have a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most likely location for his tumor?

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Within the triangle formed by the junction of the second and third portions of the duodenum, the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas, and the junction of the cystic and common bile duct Most gastrinomas are located within the gastrinoma triangle—defined by the junction of the second and third portions of the duodenum, the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas, and the junction of the cystic and common bile duct.

Highyeild:

In 70-90% of patients, primary gastrinoma is found in Passaro's triangle, but whole-body imaging is required due to the possibility of gastrinomas appearing anywhere in the body. SSTR (octreotide) scintigraphy in combination with CT is the test of choice, and EUS can be helpful in localizing tumors in the pancreatic head or duodenal wall. MEN1 syndrome should be ruled out before surgery, and surgical treatment is justified in patients with sporadic gastrinomas. Approximately 50% of gastrinomas metastasize to lymph nodes or the liver, and patients who meet the criteria for operability should undergo exploration for possible removal of the tumor. Pancreatic tumors are usually larger than tumors arising in the duodenum, and more often they have lymph node metastases.

Despite the lack of success in achieving a biochemical cure, long-term survival rates are good, even in patients with liver metastases. In this test, a fasting gastrin level is measured before administration of intravenous secretin, and further samples of serum gastrin are obtained at 2, 5, 10, and 20 minutes after secretin administration. A rise in serum gastrin levels greater than 200 pg/mL above baseline after secretin administration is found in patients with ZES.

Patients with ZES may present with abdominal pain, peptic ulcer disease, severe esophagitis, and diarrhea. In the era of effective antacid therapy, the presentation of ZES can be less dramatic, and multiple ulcers in atypical locations that fail to respond to antacids should raise suspicion for ZES. The diagnosis of ZES is made by measuring the serum gastrin level, but patients must stop taking proton pump inhibitors for accurate testing. Other conditions can cause elevated gastrin levels, including pernicious anemia, treatment with proton pump inhibitors, renal failure, G-cell hyperplasia, atrophic gastritis, retained or excluded antrum, and gastric outlet obstruction. In equivocal cases, a secretin stimulation test may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis of ZES.

questions.text: A 60-year-old previously healthy businessman notices that his eyes are yellow and he has been losing weight. On physical examination, the patient has jaundice and scleral icterus with a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound demonstrates biliary ductal dilation without gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Computed tomography (CT) scan Painless jaundice with weight loss is suspicious for pancreatic cancer involving the head or uncinate process of the pancreas. A helical contrast-enhanced CT scan is the most appropriate study to evaluate for a pancreatic mass. CT has a specificity of 95% or better with sensitivity exceeding 95% for tumors larger than 2 cm in diameter.

Highyeild:

Carcinoma Pancreas is a type of cancer that originates in the pancreas, with the most common type being pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The majority of PDAC cases occur in the head of the pancreas, with a smaller percentage occurring in the body and tail. Management: More than 85% of patients with ductal adenocarcinoma have advanced disease and are not suitable for resection. If imaging shows a potentially resectable tumor , surgical resection should be considered as it offers the only chance of a cure, albeit a small one. For patients with locally advanced or metastatic disease , the primary objective should be to relieve symptoms, improve quality of life, and extend survival, rather than achieving a cure. Patients with pancreatic cancer fall into four categories: resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced and unresectable, and metastatic. Resectable patients should be offered surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Borderline resectable patients may be offered neoadjuvant chemotherapy with or without chemoradiotherapy, followed by surgical resection if the disease has been downstaged. Adjuvant therapy should follow. Locally advanced and unresectable patient s should be offered systemic chemotherapy , with surgery being a possibility in a small cohort who get downstaged. Metastatic patients should be offered systemic chemotherapy. If a cystic tumor is encountered, regardless of size, surgical resection should be considered as it carries a reasonable chance of cure. Tumors of the ampulla have a good prognosis and should be resected if possible, as should some rare tumors and neuroendocrine lesions.

In a series of >100 patients treated with total pancreatectomy, half of all late deaths were due to iatrogenic hypoglycemia. questions.text: Which of the following signs have been known to occur in acute pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Solution:

In severe acute pancreatitis, a laparotomy must be done in all cases of pancreatic necrosis. In severe acute pancreatitis, a laparotomy is not always necessary for pancreatic necrosis. Instead, management can involve a combination of antibiotics, enteral nutrition, and minimally invasive interventions such as percutaneous drainage or endoscopic necrosectomy.

A superior mesenteric artery aneurysm can occur. The anatomical position of the superior mesenteric vessels behind the neck and between the inferior border and uncinate process of the pancreas makes these vessels vulnerable to compression and inflammation, resulting in an aneurysm (sometimes referred to as a pseudoaneurysm) of the artery and thrombosis of the vein. The rupture of such an aneurysm can be a very serious complication and challenging to treat. Pleural effusion does occur following acute pancreatitis and may require aspiration. Option: D.
